column1: - There are many features in the Komodo Ecosystem that can make an asset chain's daemon produce non-standard coinbase transactions. Examples include an assetchain parameter that creates new coins for a specified pubkey in every block or a CC module that adds outputs to the coinbase transaction.
- This can be dealt using a mode called `disablecb`

- The block template produced using this mode doesn't have the `""coinbasetxn"": { ... } json object` but adds the coinbase transction to the `""transactions"":[ ... ] array` just like a regular transaction.
- Now the pool software can use the `""transactions"":[ ... ] array` to create a block and take fees in the payment processor.
this is what I am adding to the docs. Any corrections/additions?";"";"shexy (1)";
232679450301431808;"blackjok3r#3181";"16-Mar-19 12:36 PM";"yes thats exactly how it works";"";"游녨 (1)";

column2: slush came up with a ""middle man"" theory for a pool to get the relevant data from the daemon and have the pool decide what work to dole out to workers.
at least)
column3: not every worker is working with the exact same random variable.

column1: This gives the pool both greater control and
column2: in theory
column3: a greater chance of finding a block.

column1: Core developers loved slush and this new theory so much that the code for giving a miner work directly was entirely stripped out of the code and the ""stratum"" method became the new way of doing things";"";"";
